Message.Title: Tough Times for MS
Message.Msg: NPD research published some horrible news for Microsoft (MSFT) this week: • Despite releasing an entirely new operating system on October 22 of this year, WindowsPC sales shrank 21 percent between 10/21 and 11/17 versus the same period last year. • Windows 8 tablet sales during that period were "almost nonexistent" — just 1 percent of all Windows 8 sales. "It hasn't made the market any worse, but it hasn't stimulated things either," Stephen Baker, an analyst at NPD, told The New York Times. "It hasn't provided the impetus to sales everybody hoped for." No kidding. On Thursday, we reported other bad news: • Asus CFO David Chang's comment that "demand for Windows 8 is not that good right now." • Microsoft cut its order of Surface tablets for the year to two million units, down from four million. This is a very scary time for Microsoft.

Message.Title: Tough Times for MS
Message.Msg: NPD research published some horrible news for Microsoft (MSFT) this week: • Despite releasing an entirely new operating system on October 22 of this year, WindowsPC sales shrank 21 percent between 10/21 and 11/17 versus the same period last year. • Windows 8 tablet sales during that period were "almost nonexistent" — just 1 percent of all Windows 8 sales. Message.Title: Microsoft: Abandon Ship Before It Sinks
Message.Msg: Google it. Quoting from Seeking Alpha: Conclusions Compared to Microsoft's budget, Windows 8 is underperforming. The Surface RT is heavily underperforming. The upcoming Surface Pro is going to underperform, and for a few simple reasons: it's going head to head with the iPad, the absolute king of the hill in the tablet market, offering way less (e.g. battery life) and costing much more (at least $70). These products represented the last chances Microsoft had to maintain its position in the declining PC market while building a new position in the tablet market: the company misfired badly. I say, head for the lifeboats, and abandon this sinking ship before it's too late.

Message.Title: The reason I am making you sell today
Message.Msg: . Microsoft (MSFT) Of all the companies we looked at, Microsoft seems to be the most likely to approve a special one-time dividend. The company has a massive cash reserve of around $51 billion, versus just $11.9 billion in debt. The company’s insider ownership isn’t super high, but at 9.1%, insiders do own more of Microsoft than your typical S&P 500 company. Microsoft has a regular dividend yield of 3.4%, and a payout ratio of 30, which is not too high to believe that we could see it announce a special one-time dividend before the end of the year.

Topic.Title: What is the incentive for Obama to resolve the "cliff" issue this year?

Message.Msg: The president is lying to the misinformed public. Rich Paid More Revenue Under Bush Tax Cuts While progressives attack the Bush tax cuts and President Barack Obama wants to let them expire for families making over $250,000, figures released by the IRS show the wealthiest 1% actually paid more in taxes after the Bush tax cuts were passed, and the bottom half of taxpayers actually paid less in income taxes. According to IRS data, the “richest 1% paid $84 billion more in taxes in 2007 than they had in 2000,” a 23% increase. In addition, their “share of the overall income tax burden grew, climbing from 37% in 2000 to 40% in 2007.” All this occurred even though their rates went down. The IRS numbers also found the bottom half of taxpayers “paid $6 billion less in income taxes in 2007 than they had seven years earlier,” which is a 16% decrease, and “their share of the total income tax burden actually went from 3.9% to 2.9%.” Further, as Investors Business Daily noted, the Bush tax cuts also pushed millions of people off of the tax rolls entirely because Bush “doubled the per-child tax credit to $1,000 and lowered the bottom rate to 10%.”

Topic.Title: What year will MSFT collapse?

Message.Msg: The company has become a follower and not a leader at this point. Every day that goes by they are losing market share to competition. They keep railroading these licensing deals down enterprises throat and that will eventually backfire as companies are switching their platforms. Employees are already demanding a switch and you're seeing that happen with iPads and iMacs. Apple has quietly become the largest computer company, if you consider the iPad a computer. Bottom line is that Mr. Softie has not been able to innovate on their own, and have lost any connection with the consumer. Their business still lies with the enterprise side - but for how long? 5 years ago this stock was $36.12 pps, and today it closed at $26.43 pps. Oh, yes they do issue quarterly dividends - whoopee!!! Message.Msg: A new report just out from the Internal Revenue Service reveals that 36 of President Obama's executive office staff owe the country $833,970 in back taxes. These people working for Mr. Fair Share apparently haven't paid any share, let alone their fair share. Previous reports have shown how well-paid Obama's White House staff is, with 457 aides pulling down more than $37 million last year. That's up seven workers and nearly $4 million from the Bush administration's last year. Nearly one-third of Obama's aides make more than $100,000 with 21 being paid the top White House salary of $172,200, each. The IRS' 2010 delinquent tax revelations come as part of a required annual agency report on federal employees' tax compliance. Turns out, an awful lot of folks being paid by taxpayers are not paying their own income taxes. The report finds that thousands of federal employees owe the country more than $3.4 billion in back taxes. That's up 3% in the past year, How about starting with what the Obama groupies owe. Topic.Title: What year will MSFT collapse?

Message.Msg: Windows 8 and the Surface tablets will turn out to be among the most successful products in Microsoft's history. But not because they achieve record sales. To the contrary. Windows 8 will produce mediocre results and the Surface will be a complete bust, perhaps even discontinued sometime in 2013. But together Windows 8 and the Surface could be the last straw that compels Microsoft's board to give Balmer his long, long overdue walking papers. Under his maladministration Microsoft has managed to miss every major trend in consumer technology - smartphones, tablets, search, social media, etc. He has been an unmitigated disaster for all Microsoft shareholders - except himself, ensconced as he among the top 20 on the Forbes 400 list. His tenure represents a blot on Gates' legacy as well, who could have forced him out at any time over the past ten years but didn't. Maybe the board can begin undoing the damage by hiring somebody like Scott Forstall to run the company.

Message.Title: Gorver Norquist won't allow Boehner to bring middle class tax cuts to a vote.
Message.Msg: Grover has Boehner by the short hairs. But Nancy Pelosi, middle class warrior is taking action. "If Speaker Boehner refuses to schedule this widely-supported bill for a vote, Democrats will introduce a discharge petition to automatically bring to the floor the Senate-passed middle class tax cuts," Pelosi said in a statement. The Democratic leader first warned of a discharge petition on Friday. Under a "discharge petition," a bill can be brought to the floor without going through a committee or without approval of House leadership. The bill would need an absolute majority - 218 votes - to pass. While there are only 192 Democrats in the House, some Republicans have expressed support for the bill. ONCE THE MIDDLE CLASS TAX CUTS ARE PASSED NORQUIST IS DONE. HE HAS NO MORE CARDS LEFT.
